content.title: Cholesterol Embolization Syndrome (Atheroembolism)
content.definition: Systemic embolic disease caused by spontaneous or iatrogenic release of cholesterol crystals from ulcerated atherosclerotic plaques, lodging in small and medium arterioles causing mechanical occlusion and inflammatory response. Often triggered by vascular procedures or anticoagulation.

key_concepts.description: Cholesterol crystals dislodge from atherosclerotic plaques → travel distally → lodge in small arterioles (100-200 μm) → mechanical obstruction + foreign body inflammatory reaction → end-organ damage
Vascular procedures (catheterization, angiography, surgery); anticoagulation/thrombolysis (exposes ulcerated plaque); spontaneous from unstable plaque
Recent vascular procedure + livedo reticularis + acute renal failure. Onset typically 1-4 weeks after trigger (unlike contrast nephropathy at 48-72h)
Blue toe syndrome (purple/blue toes with preserved pulses); livedo reticularis (mottled, lace-like pattern); gangrene; ulceration; often bilateral and affecting distal extremities
Progressive renal failure over weeks to months; may mimic contrast nephropathy but later onset and persistent; can require dialysis
GI: abdominal pain, GI bleeding, pancreatitis; CNS: stroke, confusion; Retinal: Hollenhorst plaques (cholesterol crystals in retinal arteries); splenic infarcts
Eosinophilia (60-80% of cases); elevated ESR/CRP; low complement; eosinophiluria; often normal or mildly elevated creatinine initially progressing over weeks
Clinical suspicion + characteristic findings; skin biopsy shows cholesterol clefts in arterioles; fundoscopy for Hollenhorst plaques; no specific test
CIN: onset 48-72h, usually reversible by 7-10 days; Cholesterol embolization: onset 1-4 weeks, progressive, persistent/irreversible
Supportive care; avoid further vascular intervention if possible; statins (stabilize plaque); discontinue anticoagulation if possible; dialysis if needed; prognosis often poor
High morbidity and mortality (up to 80% 1-year mortality in severe cases); survivors often have chronic renal impairment; no proven therapy reverses process

learning_objectives: Define cholesterol embolization syndrome and identify triggers
Recognize the classic triad (procedure + livedo + renal failure)
Distinguish from contrast-induced nephropathy by timing
Understand the poor prognosis and lack of specific treatment
clinical_pearls: Blue toes with palpable pulses = cholesterol embolization
Onset 1-4 weeks after procedure (CIN is 48-72 hours)
Hollenhorst plaques on fundoscopy = retinal cholesterol emboli
Mortality up to 80% in severe cases
Statins help stabilize plaques - continue/start them
common_mistakes: Missing the diagnosis (think of it after vascular procedures)
